clinical_study.official_title: An Open-label, Prospective, Randomized, Controlled Clinical Trial of the Use of Reduced Duration Versus Standard Duration Steroid Replacement Therapy for Acute Adrenal Insufficiency in Patients With Septic Shock

brief_summary.textblock: Randomized controlled trial evaluating the duration of steroid replacement therapy in patients with adrenal insufficiency and septic shock. Patients will be randomized to receive either hydrocortisone 50 mg IV every six hours for seven days (control) or hydrocortisone 50 mg IV every six hours until 24 hours after achievement of hemodynamic stability (MAP > 65 mm Hg off of vasopressors).

clinical_study.why_stopped: Unable to meet enrollment goal prior to PI transfer

primary_outcome.measure: The primary outcome measure for this study is the number of hours receiving steroid dosing.

secondary_outcome.measure: A secondary outcome measure will be the difference between daily glucose levels, insulin requirements, and length of stay in the ICU.

arm_group.description: Corticosteroids discontinued 24 hours after cessation of vasopressor therapy or 7 days, which ever comes first.
Standard corticosteroid therapy given for 7 days as treatment for adrenal insufficiency during septic shock.

intervention.description: Cessation of corticosteroids 24 hours after cessation of vasopressors
Administer daily for 7 days after diagnosis of acute adrenal insufficiency during septic shock

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients who are 18 years of age or older
- Patients who sign informed consent or are represented by a legally authorized representative to provide consent on behalf of the patient
- Patients with septic shock meeting the ACCM/SCCM consensus conference definitions for septic shock
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with documented allergic or anaphylactic reactions to corticosteroids
- Patients who have received steroid therapy within 6 months of presentation
- Patients who have received steroids during their hospital admission, with the exception of a single dose of dexamethasone
- Patients who have received etomidate in the preceding 12 hours
- Patients who have had a prior adrenalectomy or a known history of adrenal disease (documented adrenal insufficiency or Cushing syndrome).
- Documented Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infection
- Pregnancy
- Allergies to adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) or corticosteroids
- Administration of additional medications which may suppress the hypothalamic-pituitary axis:
- Ketoconazole
- Aminoglutethimide
- Mitotane
- Megestrol acetate
- Suramin
